metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: model satellite motion (artificial, Moon, planet) as uniform circular orbital motion: a = v²/r = 4π²r/T²

centripetal_acceleration_formula.name: Centripetal Acceleration Formula
centripetal_acceleration_formula.correct: Centripetal acceleration equals v²/r or 4π²r/T². Both forms are equivalent for uniform circular motion.

a = vr.error: Wrong operation. Acceleration involves v² divided by r, not multiplied.
a = vr.fix: a = v²/r. Speed is squared and then divided by radius.
a = vr.action: Check units: (m/s)²/m = m/s². Does vr give m/s²?

a = v/r.fix: a = v²/r. The v must be squared.
a = v/r.action: Derive from F = mv²/r and F = ma. What do you get?

a = 4πr/T².fix: It's 4π²r/T². Both 4 and π are squared together.
a = 4πr/T².action: Start from v = 2πr/T. Substitute into a = v²/r.

a = 4π²r/T.fix: a = 4π²r/T². The period T must be squared.
a = 4π²r/T.action: Check units: r/T gives m/s, not m/s². Need T².

persistent.gap: You're not remembering the formula structure correctly.
persistent.action: Derive a = 4π²r/T² from a = v²/r and v = 2πr/T. Show every step.

centripetal_force_gravity.name: Gravity as Centripetal Force
centripetal_force_gravity.correct: For satellites in orbit, gravity provides the centripetal force. No other force acts on the satellite.

tension.error: There's no string in space. Satellites aren't attached to anything.
tension.fix: Gravity alone keeps satellites in orbit. No contact forces.
tension.action: List forces on a satellite: only Fg. No normal, no tension.

normal force.error: No surface contact in orbit. Satellites are in free fall.
normal force.fix: Normal force requires surface contact. Satellites float in vacuum.
normal force.action: What touches a satellite in space? Nothing.

centrifugal force.error: Centrifugal force is fictional. It's not a real force.
centrifugal force.fix: Only gravity acts. 'Centrifugal' describes a reference frame effect, not a force.
centrifugal force.action: Draw a free body diagram. Real forces only. What's there?

friction.error: No friction in the vacuum of space.
friction.fix: Friction requires contact with a surface or medium. Space is nearly empty.
friction.action: What could cause friction on a satellite? Nothing in vacuum.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what forces act on orbiting objects.
persistent.action: For any satellite problem, start with: only force = gravity. Always.

acceleration_direction.name: Direction of Centripetal Acceleration
acceleration_direction.correct: Centripetal acceleration always points toward the centre of the circular path.

in the direction of motion.error: That would change speed, not direction.
in the direction of motion.action: Draw velocity and acceleration vectors. They're perpendicular.

outward from the centre.error: That's the centrifugal direction, not centripetal.
outward from the centre.action: Etymology: petal comes from Latin 'petere' meaning to seek.

tangent to the path.error: That's the direction of velocity, not acceleration.
tangent to the path.fix: Velocity is tangent. Acceleration is radial (toward centre).
tangent to the path.action: Draw both vectors on a satellite orbit. Different directions.

perpendicular to gravity.error: Gravity IS the centripetal force. They're the same direction.
perpendicular to gravity.fix: For satellites, gravity points toward centre = centripetal direction.
perpendicular to gravity.action: Where does gravity point? Toward Earth's centre. That's centripetal.

persistent.gap: You're confusing velocity direction with acceleration direction.
persistent.action: Remember: velocity is tangent, acceleration is radial. Draw diagrams.

orbital_speed_formula.name: Orbital Speed Formula
orbital_speed_formula.correct: Orbital speed v = √(GM/r). Speed depends on the mass being orbited (M) and orbital radius (r).

v = GM/r.fix: v = √(GM/r). The entire fraction is under the root.
v = GM/r.action: Check units: GM/r gives m³/s². Need square root for m/s.

v = √(Gm/r).error: Wrong mass. Use M (central body), not m (satellite).
v = √(Gm/r).fix: Satellite mass doesn't affect orbital speed. Only central body mass matters.
v = √(Gm/r).action: A feather and a hammer orbit at the same speed. Why? Mass cancels.

v = √(GMr).error: r should be in denominator, not numerator.
v = √(GMr).fix: v = √(GM/r). Bigger orbit means slower speed.
v = √(GMr).action: Check: does your formula give slower v for bigger r?

v = 2πr/T.error: That's a kinematic definition, not derived from gravity.
v = 2πr/T.fix: Both are correct. v = 2πr/T is general. v = √(GM/r) includes gravity.
v = 2πr/T.action: Use v = √(GM/r) when you know M. Use v = 2πr/T when you know T.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting orbital mechanics to gravitational formulas.
persistent.action: Derive v = √(GM/r) from Fg = mv²/r and Fg = GMm/r². Show every step.

orbital_speed_independence.name: Orbital Speed Independence of Satellite Mass
orbital_speed_independence.correct: Orbital speed doesn't depend on satellite mass. All satellites at the same radius orbit at the same speed.

directly proportional to mass.error: Satellite mass cancels out. Heavier satellites don't orbit faster.
directly proportional to mass.fix: From Fg = mv²/r, the m appears on both sides and cancels.
directly proportional to mass.action: Write GMm/r² = mv²/r. Divide both sides by m. What's left?

inversely proportional to mass.error: Mass doesn't appear in the final formula at all.
inversely proportional to mass.fix: v = √(GM/r) has no satellite mass m. It cancelled out.
inversely proportional to mass.action: Look at v = √(GM/r). Where is m? Nowhere.

proportional to the square of mass.error: Mass has no effect on orbital speed whatsoever.
proportional to the square of mass.fix: A tiny satellite and a massive one orbit at identical speeds at the same r.
proportional to the square of mass.action: Moon's speed doesn't depend on Moon's mass. Just Earth's mass and r.

increases with increasing mass.error: More mass doesn't mean faster orbit. Mass cancels.
increases with increasing mass.fix: ISS and a grain of dust at same height orbit at same speed.
increases with increasing mass.action: Check Apollo missions: spacecraft mass changed but orbital speed didn't.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why satellite mass cancels in orbital mechanics.
persistent.action: Derive orbital speed from scratch. Watch where m cancels. It's the key insight.

orbital_period_formula.name: Orbital Period Formula
orbital_period_formula.correct: T² = 4π²r³/(GM). Period squared is proportional to radius cubed.

T² = 4π²r²/(GM).error: Wrong power on r. It's r³, not r².
T² = 4π²r²/(GM).fix: Kepler's third law: T² ∝ r³. The radius is cubed.
T² = 4π²r²/(GM).action: Check: does doubling r give 2√2 times longer period?

T = 4π²r³/(GM).fix: T² = 4π²r³/(GM). Then take square root for T.
T = 4π²r³/(GM).action: Check units: 4π²r³/(GM) gives s², not s. Need T².

T² = 4πr³/(GM).fix: It's 4π², not 4π. Both the 4 and the π come from 2π.
T² = 4πr³/(GM).action: Derive from v = 2πr/T and v = √(GM/r). The 4π² emerges.

T² = 4π²r³(GM).fix: Bigger central mass means shorter period, so GM divides.
T² = 4π²r³(GM).action: Jupiter's moons orbit faster than Earth's because M is bigger.

persistent.gap: You're not remembering Kepler's third law correctly.
persistent.action: Write T² ∝ r³ ten times. Then derive 4π²r³/(GM) from circular motion.

period_radius_relationship.name: Period-Radius Relationship
period_radius_relationship.correct: Orbital period increases with orbital radius. Larger orbits take longer to complete.

T decreases as r increases.error: Opposite. Bigger orbits have longer periods.
T decreases as r increases.fix: T ∝ r^(3/2). As r increases, T increases even faster.
T decreases as r increases.action: Mars is further than Earth. Does it orbit faster or slower?

T is independent of r.action: Compare ISS (90 min) to geostationary (24 hr). Different r, different T.

T is directly proportional to r.error: Not quite. T ∝ r^(3/2), not r^1.
T is directly proportional to r.fix: Double the radius → period increases by factor of 2√2 ≈ 2.83.
T is directly proportional to r.action: Calculate: if r doubles, by what factor does T change?

T is inversely proportional to r.error: Opposite relationship. Bigger r means bigger T.
T is inversely proportional to r.fix: T ∝ r^(3/2). Positive exponent = direct relationship.
T is inversely proportional to r.action: Moon's orbital period (27 days) vs ISS (90 min). Which r is bigger?

persistent.gap: You don't understand the T-r relationship in orbits.
persistent.action: Memorise: larger orbit = longer period. Verify with T² ∝ r³.

speed_radius_relationship.name: Speed-Radius Relationship
speed_radius_relationship.correct: Orbital speed decreases with orbital radius. Satellites in higher orbits move slower.

v increases as r increases.fix: v = √(GM/r). r is in denominator, so bigger r = smaller v.
v increases as r increases.action: Mercury orbits faster than Neptune. Why? Smaller r.

v is independent of r.fix: v = √(GM/r) shows clear dependence on r.
v is independent of r.action: Compare ISS speed to Moon's speed. Different r, different v.

v is directly proportional to r.error: Inverse, not direct. More r means less v.
v is directly proportional to r.fix: v ∝ 1/√r. Positive r in denominator = inverse relationship.
v is directly proportional to r.action: If r doubles, v becomes 1/√2 ≈ 0.71 of original.

v is proportional to r².action: Check the formula: where does r appear? Under a root in denominator.

persistent.gap: You have the speed-radius relationship backwards.
persistent.action: Remember: higher orbit = slower speed. Derive from v = √(GM/r).

orbital_radius_definition.name: Orbital Radius Definition
orbital_radius_definition.correct: Orbital radius is measured from the CENTRE of the planet, not from its surface.

altitude above surface.fix: r = altitude + planet radius. Measure from centre to centre.
altitude above surface.action: ISS at 400 km altitude: r = 400 + 6370 = 6770 km.

diameter of orbit.fix: Radius is half the diameter. r = d/2.
diameter of orbit.action: If orbit diameter is 14000 km, r = 7000 km.

circumference of orbit.fix: Circumference = 2πr. Divide by 2π to get r.
circumference of orbit.action: If circumference is 44000 km, r = 44000/(2π) ≈ 7000 km.

distance between centres.error: Careful - this IS correct for point masses.
distance between centres.fix: For satellites (tiny) orbiting planets (large), this equals orbital radius.
distance between centres.action: Good. Now remember: include planet radius when given altitude.

persistent.gap: You're confusing altitude with orbital radius.
persistent.action: Always check: does the problem give altitude or radius? Add R_planet if needed.

geostationary_orbit.name: Geostationary Orbit
geostationary_orbit.correct: A geostationary satellite has period = 24 hours, orbits above equator, same direction as Earth's rotation.

any satellite with T = 24 hours.error: Must also be above equator and rotate in correct direction.
any satellite with T = 24 hours.fix: Three conditions: T = 24 hr, above equator, eastward orbit.
any satellite with T = 24 hours.action: A polar orbit with T = 24 hr is NOT geostationary. Why?

satellite that doesn't move.error: It moves. It just appears stationary from Earth's surface.
satellite that doesn't move.fix: Geostationary satellites orbit at ~7 km/s. Earth rotates beneath them.
satellite that doesn't move.action: Calculate: what speed at r = 42000 km gives T = 24 hr?

orbit at any altitude.error: Geostationary altitude is fixed at ~36000 km.
orbit at any altitude.fix: Only ONE radius gives T = 24 hours. r = ∛(GMT²/4π²).
orbit at any altitude.action: Calculate geostationary radius using M_Earth and T = 86400 s.

orbit in any direction.error: Must orbit eastward (same as Earth's rotation).
orbit in any direction.fix: Westward orbit would appear to move rapidly across the sky.
orbit in any direction.action: Imagine Earth from above North Pole. Which way does it spin?

persistent.gap: You don't understand all the conditions for geostationary orbit.
persistent.action: List all three conditions. Explain why each is necessary.

free_fall_in_orbit.name: Free Fall in Orbit
free_fall_in_orbit.correct: Astronauts in orbit are in constant free fall. They're weightless because no normal force acts on them.

no gravity in space.error: Gravity is still ~90% of surface value at ISS altitude.
no gravity in space.fix: Gravity keeps them in orbit. They're falling but also moving sideways.
no gravity in space.action: Calculate g at 400 km altitude. It's about 8.7 m/s², not zero.

gravity is cancelled.error: Gravity isn't cancelled. It's the centripetal force.
gravity is cancelled.fix: Nothing cancels gravity. Astronauts fall WITH the spacecraft.
gravity is cancelled.action: Both astronaut and spacecraft accelerate at g. No relative motion.

escape from Earth's gravity.error: If they escaped gravity, they'd fly off in a straight line.
escape from Earth's gravity.fix: Gravity curves their path into a circle. Still very much present.
escape from Earth's gravity.action: What happens to a spacecraft if gravity suddenly vanishes?

centrifugal force balances gravity.error: Centrifugal force isn't real. No force balances gravity.
centrifugal force balances gravity.fix: Gravity provides the centripetal acceleration. Unbalanced force = acceleration.
centrifugal force balances gravity.action: Draw free body diagram. Only Fg. Net force ≠ 0, that's why they accelerate.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why orbiting astronauts feel weightless.
persistent.action: Key insight: they're falling but never hitting ground. Einstein's happiest thought.

kepler_third_law.name: Kepler's Third Law
kepler_third_law.correct: For all satellites orbiting the same body, T²/r³ is constant. This ratio depends only on the central mass.

T/r = constant.error: Wrong powers. It's T² and r³.
T/r = constant.fix: T²/r³ = 4π²/(GM). The ratio involves squares and cubes.
T/r = constant.action: Check with Moon and ISS data. Does T/r give same value? No.

T²/r² = constant.error: Wrong power on r. It's r³, not r².
T²/r² = constant.fix: T² ∝ r³ is Kepler's third law.
T²/r² = constant.action: Derive: what power of r makes T²/r^n constant?

T³/r² = constant.fix: T² goes with r³, not the other way around.

different for each satellite.error: Same ratio for all satellites of the same central body.
different for each satellite.fix: Constant = 4π²/(GM). Only depends on M of central body.
different for each satellite.action: Calculate T²/r³ for Moon and ISS. Same value (for Earth).

persistent.gap: You haven't memorised Kepler's third law correctly.
persistent.action: T²/r³ = constant. Calculate this ratio for 3 different Earth satellites.

centripetal_acceleration.title: Understanding Centripetal Acceleration in Orbits
centripetal_acceleration.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of centripetal acceleration for satellites.

sentences.text: When modelling satellite motion as uniform circular motion, the centripetal acceleration can be calculated using a = {{d1}} or equivalently a = {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What operation relates speed squared to radius?

d2.tooltip: Period T appears squared in the denominator.

sentences.text: The centripetal acceleration for a satellite in orbit always points {{d3}}. For satellites, the force providing this acceleration is {{d4}}.

d3.correct: toward the centre of the orbit

d4.tooltip: What force acts on a satellite in the vacuum of space?

sentences.text: For uniform circular orbital motion, the satellite's speed remains {{d5}}, but its velocity constantly changes because its {{d6}} is changing.

d5.tooltip: What does 'uniform' mean in uniform circular motion?

d6.tooltip: Velocity is a vector. What two properties does a vector have?

orbital_speed.title: Understanding Orbital Speed
orbital_speed.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of orbital speed.

sentences.text: The orbital speed of a satellite can be calculated using v = {{d1}}, where M is the mass of the {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: The formula involves a square root of a fraction.

d2.tooltip: Is it Earth's mass or the satellite's mass that determines orbital speed?

sentences.text: A key insight of orbital mechanics is that orbital speed is {{d3}} of the satellite's mass. This means a heavy satellite and a light satellite at the same radius orbit at {{d4}} speed.

d3.tooltip: Does the satellite's mass appear in v = √(GM/r)?

d4.tooltip: If mass doesn't affect speed, what happens to two different masses?

sentences.text: Orbital speed can also be calculated using v = {{d5}}, which shows that speed equals the {{d6}} divided by the period.

d5.tooltip: What is the circumference of a circle?

d6.tooltip: Speed = distance/time. What distance does a satellite travel in one period?

orbital_period.title: Understanding Orbital Period
orbital_period.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of orbital period.

sentences.text: The orbital period formula can be expressed as T² = {{d1}}, showing that T² is proportional to {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What power is r raised to in Kepler's third law?

d2.tooltip: Kepler's third law: T-squared is proportional to r to what power?

sentences.text: When comparing satellites orbiting the same central body, the ratio {{d3}} has the same value for all satellites because it equals {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What combination of T and r is constant?

d4.tooltip: This constant depends only on the central body's mass.

sentences.text: As orbital radius increases, the orbital period {{d5}}. This relationship can be expressed as T ∝ {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Does the Moon take longer to orbit than the ISS?

d6.tooltip: If T² ∝ r³, what is T proportional to?

orbital_relationships.title: Understanding Orbital Relationships
orbital_relationships.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of the relationships between orbital quantities.

sentences.text: As orbital radius increases, orbital speed {{d1}} because v ∝ {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Does Mercury or Neptune orbit faster?

d2.tooltip: In v = √(GM/r), is r in the numerator or denominator?

sentences.text: The orbital radius is measured from the {{d3}} of the planet to the satellite. For a satellite at altitude h above Earth's surface, r = {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Do we measure from the surface or the centre?

d4.tooltip: What must you add to altitude to get orbital radius?

sentences.text: A geostationary satellite has an orbital period of {{d5}} and must orbit above Earth's {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: How long does Earth take to complete one rotation?

d6.tooltip: Where must the satellite orbit to appear stationary?

centripetal_acceleration.title: Applying Centripetal Acceleration
centripetal_acceleration.instructions: Apply your understanding of centripetal acceleration to these orbital scenarios.

sentences.text: For a satellite in uniform circular orbit, the only force acting on it is {{d1}}, which provides the {{d2}} acceleration needed to maintain circular motion.

d1.tooltip: What single force keeps satellites in orbit?

d2.tooltip: Acceleration toward the centre is called what?

sentences.text: If a satellite's orbital radius doubles while maintaining uniform circular motion, its centripetal acceleration becomes {{d3}} of the original value because a ∝ {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: If a = v²/r and v ∝ 1/√r, what happens to a when r doubles?

d4.tooltip: Combine a = v²/r with v = √(GM/r). What power of r results?

sentences.text: Astronauts in the ISS experience {{d5}} because they are in {{d6}} along with the spacecraft.

d5.tooltip: Is gravity actually zero in the ISS?

d6.tooltip: What kind of motion describes a falling object?

orbital_speed.title: Applying Orbital Speed Concepts
orbital_speed.instructions: Apply your understanding of orbital speed to these scenarios.

sentences.text: The Moon and a small satellite both orbit Earth. The Moon has much greater mass, but if they were at the same orbital radius, they would have {{d1}} orbital speed because orbital speed depends on {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Does the orbiting object's mass affect its speed?

d2.correct: only the central body's mass and orbital radius

sentences.text: Mercury orbits the Sun faster than Neptune because Mercury has a {{d3}} orbital radius, and speed is {{d4}} proportional to the square root of orbital radius.

d3.tooltip: Which planet is closer to the Sun?

d4.tooltip: As r increases, does v increase or decrease?

sentences.text: To calculate the orbital speed of a satellite at altitude h above Earth, you must first determine r = {{d5}}, then substitute into {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: How do you convert altitude to orbital radius?

d6.tooltip: What formula gives orbital speed from r and M?

orbital_period.title: Applying Orbital Period Concepts
orbital_period.instructions: Apply your understanding of orbital period to these scenarios.

sentences.text: The ISS orbits at about 400 km altitude with a period of approximately 90 minutes. The Moon at 384,000 km has a period of about 27 days. This demonstrates that {{d1}} orbits have {{d2}} periods.

d1.tooltip: Which has the larger orbital radius - ISS or Moon?

d2.tooltip: Does the Moon or ISS have the longer orbital period?

sentences.text: If a satellite's orbital radius is increased by a factor of 4, its period increases by a factor of {{d3}} because T ∝ {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: What is the square root of r³?

sentences.text: For satellites orbiting Earth, the value of T²/r³ is {{d5}} for all satellites because this ratio equals {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Does Kepler's constant depend on the satellite?

orbital_relationships.title: Applying Orbital Relationships
orbital_relationships.instructions: Apply your understanding of how orbital quantities relate to each other.

sentences.text: A geostationary satellite must orbit at a specific radius of approximately 42,000 km from Earth's centre because at this radius, the orbital period equals {{d1}}. Moving to a higher orbit would make the period {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: What happens to period when radius increases?

sentences.text: To remain in stable orbit at a smaller radius, a satellite must orbit {{d3}} because orbital speed is {{d4}} at smaller radii.

d3.tooltip: What happens to required speed at lower orbits?

d4.tooltip: From v = √(GM/r), what happens to v as r decreases?

sentences.text: The gravitational field strength at orbital height still provides {{d5}} required for circular motion. At ISS altitude, g is approximately {{d6}} of the surface value.

d5.tooltip: What role does g play in orbital motion?

d6.tooltip: Is gravity much weaker at 400 km altitude?

centripetal_acceleration.title: Mastering Centripetal Acceleration
centripetal_acceleration.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of centripetal acceleration in orbital motion.

sentences.text: The equivalence of a = v²/r and a = 4π²r/T² can be derived by substituting {{d1}} into the first equation. Both forms give the same result because they describe {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What expression for v uses circumference and period?

d2.tooltip: What type of motion do these formulas describe?

sentences.text: A common misconception is that astronauts float in space because there is no gravity. In reality, gravitational field strength at ISS altitude is about {{d3}}, and astronauts float because they are in {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Calculate g at 400 km altitude using g = GM/r².

d4.correct: continuous free fall with the spacecraft
distractors: a region where gravity is cancelled
d4.tooltip: Both astronaut and spacecraft accelerate at the same rate.

sentences.text: For a satellite in circular orbit, the centripetal acceleration equals {{d5}}, which shows why the satellite's mass {{d6}} its orbital acceleration.

d5.tooltip: The gravitational field strength is g = GM/r². This equals the centripetal acceleration.

d6.tooltip: Does the satellite's mass appear in a = GM/r²?

orbital_speed.title: Mastering Orbital Speed
orbital_speed.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of orbital speed concepts.

sentences.text: The formula v = √(GM/r) can be derived by equating gravitational force to centripetal force: {{d1}} = {{d2}}, then solving for v.

d1.tooltip: What is Newton's law of universal gravitation?

d2.tooltip: What is the formula for centripetal force?

sentences.text: When the satellite mass m cancels from both sides of the equation, we find that orbital speed depends only on {{d3}} and {{d4}}, not on the satellite's properties.

d3.tooltip: What property of Earth affects orbital speed?

d4.tooltip: What geometric property of the orbit affects speed?

sentences.text: If you compare planets orbiting the Sun, the relationship v ∝ 1/√r explains why Mercury's orbital speed is {{d5}} times faster than Earth's, since Mercury's orbital radius is approximately {{d6}} of Earth's.

d6.tooltip: Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun.

orbital_period.title: Mastering Orbital Period
orbital_period.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of orbital period relationships.

sentences.text: Kepler's third law states that for any satellite orbiting a given body, the ratio T²/r³ is {{d1}}. This can be derived by combining the equations T = 2πr/v and v = √(GM/r) to get T² = {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: Substitute and simplify the two equations.

sentences.text: The ISS completes one orbit in about 90 minutes at altitude 400 km. A geostationary satellite at 35,786 km altitude has a period of 24 hours. The ratio of their periods is about {{d3}}, while the ratio of their radii is about {{d4}}.
To find the mass of a planet from satellite observations, measure the satellite's {{d5}} and {{d6}}, then rearrange T² = 4π²r³/(GM) to solve for M.

d5.tooltip: What T stands for in the formula?

d6.tooltip: What r stands for in the formula?

orbital_relationships.title: Synthesising Orbital Relationships
orbital_relationships.instructions: Demonstrate your ability to connect and apply all orbital concepts.

sentences.text: As orbital radius increases, speed {{d1}} because v ∝ 1/√r, while period {{d2}} because T ∝ r^(3/2).

d1.tooltip: v ∝ 1/√r means v and r move in opposite directions.

d2.tooltip: T ∝ r^(3/2) means T and r move in the same direction.

sentences.text: A geostationary satellite has a period of {{d3}} and must orbit above the {{d4}} to remain stationary relative to Earth's surface.

d4.tooltip: Where is the only place a satellite can appear stationary?

sentences.text: The universality of orbital mechanics means all satellites of a given central body share the same value of {{d5}}, which equals {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: What ratio is constant for all satellites orbiting the same body?

d6.tooltip: This constant depends only on the central body's mass.
